content.text: The required functionality and performance criteria can be described in a separate document which is attached to the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Such subjective or unilateral criteria can, with the assistance of Zebracorp product line or customer team, be replaced by objective and clearly defined acceptance criteria.
content.plain_text: Replace subjective or unilateral acceptance criteria with objective, clearly defined criteria, with help from Zebracorp teams.
content.expert_insight: Objective criteria are measurable and reduce the risk of disputes, providing a clear basis for acceptance or rejection.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Reduces ambiguity and potential for disputes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should strive for objective, measurable criteria to avoid disputes.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers prefer objective criteria to clearly understand what is required for acceptance.
content.text: Such subjective or unilateral criteria can, with the assistance of Zebracorp product line or customer team, be replaced by objective and clearly defined acceptance criteria.

content.verbatim_text: In fact, this approach would be preferred over agreeing to language where we merely state that acceptance test will be passed when the deliverables ‘substantially conform’ or “materially comply” with the agreed specifications.
content.plain_text: Prefer objective criteria over vague language like 'substantially conform' or 'materially comply'.
content.expert_insight: Ambiguous terms like 'substantially conform' are frequent sources of contractual disputes; precise, objective language is always better.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Ambiguous language is prone to disputes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should avoid vague language to prevent disputes and ensure clear acceptance terms.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from clear, unambiguous criteria to avoid disputes over 'substantial' or 'material' compliance.
content.text: In fact, this approach would be preferred over agreeing to language where we merely state that acceptance test will be passed when the deliverables ‘substantially conform’ or “materially comply” with the agreed specifications.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances we can agree that minor deficiencies/errors found during the acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works will not prevent acceptance, but will be remedied by the subcontractor as part of its warranty obligations or within a certain mutually agreed timeframe.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can agree to accept deliverables with minor, non-critical deficiencies, provided the subcontractor remedies them under warranty or within an agreed timeframe.
content.expert_insight: This allows for practical flexibility, preventing project stalls over minor issues while ensuring that all deficiencies are eventually addressed.
content.conditions: Minor deficiencies/errors found during acceptance tests do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works.
content.justification: Allows for flexibility while ensuring remedies for minor issues.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept deliverables for use while ensuring minor issues are fixed post-acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can achieve acceptance even with minor issues, provided they commit to remedies.
content.text: In some instances we can agree that minor deficiencies/errors found during the acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works will not prevent acceptance, but will be remedied by the subcontractor as part of its warranty obligations or within a certain mutually agreed timeframe.

content.verbatim_text: Again, in those subcontracts where the supplier is delivering the deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer, it is naturally important that the acceptance is sufficiently aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.
content.plain_text: For subcontracts where suppliers deliver directly to Zebracorp's customers, acceptance must be aligned with Zebracorp's customer acceptance.
content.expert_insight: Reiterates the critical 'back-to-back' principle, essential for managing risk and ensuring Zebracorp's liabilities and payments are synchronized with its customer agreements.
content.conditions: Subcontracts where the supplier is delivering deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer.
content.justification: Ensures alignment with customer contracts and prevents Zebracorp from accepting supplier deliverables prematurely.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its subcontractor contracts mirror its customer acceptance terms.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' acceptance from Zebracorp will be contingent on Zebracorp's customer acceptance.
content.text: Again, in those subcontracts where the supplier is delivering the deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer, it is naturally important that the acceptance is sufficiently aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: The completion of acceptance should be subject to the successful completion of acceptance tests that are performed by either Zebracorp or our end customers, or, as applicable, both jointly.
content.plain_text: Acceptance completion should depend on successful acceptance tests performed by Zebracorp, end customers, or both jointly.
content.expert_insight: This defines Zebracorp's preferred position for who conducts the tests, emphasizing its control or alignment with customer testing.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Ensures proper verification by relevant parties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp maintains control or oversight over the acceptance testing process.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must meet acceptance criteria verified by Zebracorp or its customers.
content.text: The completion of acceptance should be subject to the successful completion of acceptance tests that are performed by either Zebracorp or our end customers, or, as applicable, both jointly.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier/subcontractor participation to the acceptance tests will be at the discretion of Zebracorp and our end customer, as applicable.
content.plain_text: Supplier/subcontractor participation in acceptance tests is at Zebracorp's and/or the end customer's discretion.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces Zebracorp's control over the testing process, allowing it to decide the level of supplier involvement.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Maintains Zebracorp's control over the testing process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains the right to decide if and how suppliers participate in tests.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' participation in tests is not guaranteed and depends on Zebracorp's discretion.
content.text: The supplier/subcontractor participation to the acceptance tests will be at the discretion of Zebracorp and our end customer, as applicable.

content.verbatim_text: The agreement should provide Zebracorp sufficient time to complete the acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: Agreements should grant Zebracorp ample time for acceptance tests.
content.expert_insight: Ensuring sufficient time is critical for thorough testing and preventing rushed, potentially incomplete, evaluations.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Allows for thorough and proper testing.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should negotiate for adequate testing periods in contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to require sufficient time for acceptance testing.
content.text: The agreement should provide Zebracorp sufficient time to complete the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Failure to complete the tests in a timely manner should not automatically lead to deemed acceptance, but the supplier/subcontractor should first be required to notify Zebracorp in writing and request Zebracorp to complete the acceptance within a reasonable time frame.
content.plain_text: Untimely test completion should not automatically trigger deemed acceptance; suppliers must first notify Zebracorp in writing and request completion within a reasonable timeframe.
content.expert_insight: This preferred position provides Zebracorp with a crucial safety net, preventing automatic acceptance due to internal delays and giving a final opportunity to complete tests.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Prevents inadvertent deemed acceptance and provides a final opportunity for Zebracorp to complete tests.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp is protected from automatic deemed acceptance due to its own delays, retaining control.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must follow a formal notification process before deemed acceptance can be triggered.
content.text: Failure to complete the tests in a timely manner should not automatically lead to deemed acceptance, but the supplier/subcontractor should first be required to notify Zebracorp in writing and request Zebracorp to complete the acceptance within a reasonable time frame.

content.verbatim_text: Acceptance should be either final, partial or conditional as indicated by Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should determine if acceptance is final, partial, or conditional.
content.expert_insight: This ensures Zebracorp maintains control over the type of acceptance granted, aligning with project needs and risk management.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Maintains Zebracorp's control over the type of acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains discretion over the nature of acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accept the type of acceptance (final, partial, conditional) as determined by Zebracorp.
content.text: Acceptance should be either final, partial or conditional as indicated by Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] shall notify Zebracorp in writing when the [Supplier] considers that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been completed in accordance with this [Agreement], and request [Zebracorp] to initiate the acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: The Supplier must notify Zebracorp in writing upon completion of works or milestones, requesting acceptance tests.
content.expert_insight: This standard clause clearly defines the supplier's obligation to initiate the acceptance process, ensuring Zebracorp is formally informed.
content.conditions: Supplier considers works or relevant milestone completed in accordance with the Agreement.
content.justification: Initiates the acceptance process and formalizes supplier communication.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp receives formal notification to begin acceptance procedures.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are obligated to formally notify Zebracorp to trigger acceptance testing.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision.
content.text: The [Supplier] shall notify Zebracorp in writing when the [Supplier] considers that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been completed in accordance with this [Agreement], and request [Zebracorp] to initiate the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question.
content.plain_text: Within 30 days of receiving a completion notice, Zebracorp must issue an acceptance certificate if works or milestones meet criteria.
content.expert_insight: This sets a clear, time-bound obligation for Zebracorp to respond, providing certainty for the supplier regarding the acceptance timeline.
content.conditions: Zebracorp receives written notice and is satisfied that works/milestone are duly completed and acceptance criteria met.
content.justification: Establishes a clear timeframe and condition for Zebracorp's acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp is obligated to act within 30 days if conditions are met.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect a response within 30 days if their deliverables meet criteria.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision.
content.text: Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question.

content.verbatim_text: Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's acceptance certificate can specify partial or conditional acceptance.
content.expert_insight: Reinforces Zebracorp's flexibility in granting different types of acceptance based on the deliverable's status.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Allows Zebracorp flexibility in the type of acceptance granted.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can tailor acceptance to the specific state of the deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must understand that acceptance may not always be final.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision.
content.text: Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate.

content.verbatim_text: In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp is not satisfied with the works or if acceptance criteria are not met, it must notify the Supplier within the specified timeframe and, upon request, provide reasons for refusal.
content.expert_insight: This ensures transparency and provides the supplier with actionable feedback, which is crucial for rectifying issues and maintaining a constructive relationship.
content.conditions: Zebracorp is not satisfied with works/milestone completion or acceptance criteria/requirements are not met.
content.justification: Ensures transparency and provides feedback to the supplier.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp is obligated to provide timely and reasoned refusal if conditions are not met.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers have a right to receive timely notification and reasons for acceptance refusal.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision.
content.text: In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action.
content.plain_text: The Supplier must promptly remedy all failures, deficiencies, and defects identified by Zebracorp or its customer during acceptance tests, and notify Zebracorp in writing upon completion of remedial action.
content.expert_insight: This clause clearly outlines the supplier's core obligation to fix any identified issues, ensuring the deliverables ultimately meet the required standards.
content.conditions: Failures, deficiencies, or defects identified during acceptance tests.
content.justification: Ensures deliverables meet agreed standards.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can expect suppliers to promptly rectify issues found during testing.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are contractually obligated to fix all identified deficiencies and inform Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision.
content.text: The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action.

content.verbatim_text: [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp will issue the acceptance certificate only after verifying that all deficiencies and defects have been remedied, and all requirements for acceptance are met.
content.expert_insight: This provides Zebracorp with a clear condition precedent for acceptance, ensuring that all issues are resolved before formal acceptance is granted.
content.conditions: Deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, works/relevant part completed, and all requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance met.
content.justification: Ensures all issues are resolved before formal acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp is not obligated to accept until all conditions are fully satisfied.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must ensure all remedies are completed and verified before expecting acceptance.
content.source_insight: Example of an acceptance procedure provision.
content.text: [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”

content.verbatim_text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.plain_text: For specific end customer projects, acceptance criteria and procedures in subcontracts must always align with the end customer's acceptance provisions.
content.expert_insight: This is a final, emphatic reiteration of the 'back-to-back' principle, underscoring its paramount importance for project-specific subcontracts to manage risk and maintain contractual consistency.
content.conditions: Subcontracts specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.justification: Ensures alignment with customer contracts and prevents Zebracorp from accepting supplier deliverables prematurely.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its subcontractor contracts mirror its customer acceptance terms.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' acceptance from Zebracorp will be contingent on Zebracorp's customer acceptance.
content.text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.

content.verbatim_text: The purpose of acceptance provisions is to enable the seller to demonstrate that deliverables sold by the seller meet the mutually agreed requirements, and for the buyer to be able to verify that such deliverables do comply with such requirements.
content.plain_text: Acceptance provisions serve to allow sellers to prove deliverables meet requirements and buyers to verify compliance.
content.expert_insight: This foundational statement highlights the dual benefit of acceptance clauses, ensuring both parties have a mechanism for validation and verification of contractual obligations.
content.justification: Explains the general objective of acceptance provisions.
content.implication_company: Enables Zebracorp to verify supplier deliverables meet agreed requirements.
content.implication_supplier: Allows suppliers to demonstrate their deliverables meet agreed requirements.
content.text: The purpose of acceptance provisions is to enable the seller to demonstrate that deliverables sold by the seller meet the mutually agreed requirements, and for the buyer to be able to verify that such deliverables do comply with such requirements.

content.verbatim_text: An acceptance in regard to its extent and effect, may be either final, conditional, or partial.
content.plain_text: Acceptance can be categorized as final, conditional, or partial based on its scope and impact.
content.expert_insight: Understanding these categories is crucial for drafting flexible and precise acceptance clauses that can accommodate various project stages and deliverable types.
content.justification: Provides context on the different forms acceptance can take.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can leverage different types of acceptance to manage risk and project phases.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers need to be aware of the different types of acceptance and their implications on payment and project completion.
content.text: An acceptance in regard to its extent and effect, may be either final, conditional, or partial.

content.verbatim_text: Common terms used in subcontracts include: PAC = Partial or Provisional Acceptance Certificate; and FAC = Final Acceptance Certificate.
content.plain_text: PAC stands for Partial or Provisional Acceptance Certificate, and FAC stands for Final Acceptance Certificate.
content.expert_insight: These acronyms are standard in many contracts, signifying key milestones in the acceptance process.
content.justification: Defines common terms related to acceptance certificates.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Common terms used in subcontracts include: PAC = Partial or Provisional Acceptance Certificate; and FAC = Final Acceptance Certificate.

content.verbatim_text: Acceptance provisions should always be drafted and reviewed with special care.
content.plain_text: Always draft and review acceptance provisions with meticulous attention.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical best practice. Poorly defined acceptance terms can lead to significant disputes, delays, and financial implications for both parties.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Acceptance provisions are essential for defining completion, revenue recognition, payment triggers, and warranty start dates.
content.implication_company: Failure to draft carefully can lead to disputes, premature payments, or warranty issues for Zebracorp.
content.implication_supplier: Ambiguous provisions can delay revenue recognition, payments, or trigger disputes for suppliers.
content.text: Acceptance provisions should always be drafted and reviewed with special care.

content.verbatim_text: Acceptance generally triggers the right for the subcontractor to invoice and get paid for its deliverables and it can stop the liquidated damages clock. Moreover, the majority of contracts stipulate that the warranty starts to run from the date of acceptance.
content.plain_text: Acceptance typically enables subcontractors to invoice and receive payment, stops liquidated damages accrual, and initiates the warranty period.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the significant financial and contractual implications of acceptance for both the buyer and the seller, making it a critical milestone.
content.justification: Explains the key effects of acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp's payment obligations, warranty period, and liquidated damages calculations are directly affected by acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' ability to recognize revenue, invoice, and stop liquidated damages is tied to acceptance, and their warranty period begins.
content.text: Acceptance generally triggers the right for the subcontractor to invoice and get paid for its deliverables and it can stop the liquidated damages clock. Moreover, the majority of contracts stipulate that the warranty starts to run from the date of acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: In cases where the subcontractor is working directly for Zebracorp in a particular customer project, the acceptance provisions would need to be aligned with the corresponding provisions of our customer contract in order to ensure that acceptance is not granted to the subcontractor before securing acceptance from the end customer.
content.plain_text: For customer projects, Zebracorp's acceptance provisions with subcontractors must align with customer contract provisions, ensuring subcontractor acceptance doesn't precede end-customer acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This 'back-to-back' alignment is crucial to prevent Zebracorp from being liable for subcontractor payments or accepting non-compliant work before the end customer has formally accepted it, thereby mitigating significant financial and reputational risk.
content.conditions: Subcontractor is working directly for Zebracorp in a particular customer project.
content.justification: To ensure acceptance is not granted to the subcontractor before securing acceptance from the end customer.
content.implication_company: Protects Zebracorp from accepting and potentially paying for deliverables that the end customer has not yet accepted, preventing a mismatch in obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' acceptance and payment may be contingent on Zebracorp's end-customer acceptance, requiring awareness of the end-customer contract terms.
content.text: In cases where the subcontractor is working directly for Zebracorp in a particular customer project, the acceptance provisions would need to be aligned with the corresponding provisions of our customer contract in order to ensure that acceptance is not granted to the subcontractor before securing acceptance from the end customer.

content.verbatim_text: Acceptance provisions are likely to have less relevance in those global sourcing contracts where the supplier is not delivering directly anything to Zebracorp’s customers and where the supplier payments are not tied to acceptance but where payments are triggered in e.g. by the delivery of materials or products to Zebracorp global hubs.
content.plain_text: Acceptance provisions are less critical in global sourcing contracts where suppliers don't deliver to Zebracorp's customers directly and payments are based on delivery to Zebracorp hubs, not acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This provides important context for when acceptance clauses can be de-emphasized or omitted, shifting the focus to delivery and warranty terms for standard component or OEM supply.
content.justification: Explains scenarios where acceptance provisions are less relevant.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can simplify contracts for component/OEM suppliers by reducing reliance on formal acceptance, if payments are tied to delivery.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in these types of contracts may have payment triggers based on delivery rather than formal acceptance.
content.text: Acceptance provisions are likely to have less relevance in those global sourcing contracts where the supplier is not delivering directly anything to Zebracorp’s customers and where the supplier payments are not tied to acceptance but where payments are triggered in e.g. by the delivery of materials or products to Zebracorp global hubs.

content.verbatim_text: In such contracts acceptance provisions may be omitted and the practical aspect of product acceptance can be dealt with the warranty provisions as long as Zebracorp’s payment obligations are not tied to acceptance.
content.plain_text: In global sourcing contracts where payments aren't tied to acceptance, acceptance provisions can be omitted, with product acceptance handled via warranty terms.
content.expert_insight: This offers a pragmatic approach for high-volume, standardized supply chains, streamlining contracting by relying on post-delivery warranty claims for quality assurance.
content.conditions: Global sourcing contracts where supplier payments are not tied to acceptance.
content.justification: To streamline contracts where formal acceptance is not a payment trigger.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can simplify contracts and rely on warranty for product quality, but must ensure payment obligations are clearly separated from acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may not face formal acceptance procedures, but remain liable for product quality under warranty provisions.
content.text: In such contracts acceptance provisions may be omitted and the practical aspect of product acceptance can be dealt with the warranty provisions as long as Zebracorp’s payment obligations are not tied to acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever the deliverables purchased by Zebracorp are subject to acceptance, we should focus on the description of acceptance procedures and the contractual acceptance criteria.
content.plain_text: When deliverables require acceptance, Zebracorp should prioritize clear descriptions of acceptance procedures and criteria.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes proactive contract drafting to prevent ambiguity, which is a common source of disputes in acceptance processes.
content.conditions: Deliverables purchased by Zebracorp are subject to acceptance.
content.justification: To ensure clarity and avoid disputes in the acceptance process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp benefits from clear procedures and criteria, reducing risk of disputes and ensuring deliverables meet expectations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from clear procedures and criteria, knowing exactly what is required for acceptance and payment.
content.text: Whenever the deliverables purchased by Zebracorp are subject to acceptance, we should focus on the description of acceptance procedures and the contractual acceptance criteria.

content.verbatim_text: The subcontractor/supplier should inform Zebracorp when the results of works or other deliverables are ready for acceptance i.e. for acceptance tests and verification.
content.plain_text: Subcontractors/suppliers must notify Zebracorp when deliverables are ready for acceptance tests and verification.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a clear trigger for Zebracorp to begin its acceptance process, ensuring timely engagement and avoiding delays.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To initiate the acceptance process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp relies on this notification to schedule and perform acceptance tests.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers have an obligation to inform Zebracorp when deliverables are ready for acceptance.
content.text: The subcontractor/supplier should inform Zebracorp when the results of works or other deliverables are ready for acceptance i.e. for acceptance tests and verification.

content.verbatim_text: The range of acceptance periods usually varies between 20-60 days, with the majority of contracts having a 30-day period. System level testing may require longer testing period.
content.plain_text: Acceptance periods typically range from 20-60 days, often 30 days, though system level testing might need more time.
content.expert_insight: This provides a benchmark for negotiating acceptance timelines, with a note that complex systems may require extended evaluation.
content.justification: Provides typical timeframes for acceptance periods.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should consider these typical periods when negotiating, and factor in longer times for complex systems.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect acceptance periods within this range and prepare for potentially longer system-level testing.
content.text: The range of acceptance periods usually varies between 20-60 days, with the majority of contracts having a 30-day period. System level testing may require longer testing period.

content.verbatim_text: Absent a contractually agreed acceptance period, acceptance may be governed by applicable laws. In e. g. section 2-606 of the United States Uniform Commercial Code (“UCC”) provides that acceptance is deemed to occur when the buyer fails to reject the goods within a “reasonable time”.
content.plain_text: Without a contractually defined acceptance period, applicable laws, like the UCC's 'reasonable time' for rejection, may govern acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This underscores the importance of explicitly defining acceptance periods in contracts to avoid relying on potentially ambiguous legal defaults.
content.justification: Provides context on legal defaults for acceptance periods.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should always strive for contractually defined acceptance periods to avoid legal interpretation of 'reasonable time'.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should push for clear acceptance timelines to avoid uncertainty and potential disputes based on 'reasonable time'.
content.text: Absent a contractually agreed acceptance period, acceptance may be governed by applicable laws. In e. g. section 2-606 of the United States Uniform Commercial Code (“UCC”) provides that acceptance is deemed to occur when the buyer fails to reject the goods within a “reasonable time”.

content.verbatim_text: In most cases the supplier/subcontractor should be allowed to participate in the site level acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: Suppliers/subcontractors should generally be permitted to participate in site-level acceptance tests.
content.expert_insight: Supplier participation can facilitate quicker issue resolution and provide valuable insights during testing, though control must remain with Zebracorp.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp may allow supplier participation to aid in testing and issue resolution, but must maintain control.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect to participate in site-level tests, which can help them understand issues and work towards acceptance.
content.text: In most cases the supplier/subcontractor should be allowed to participate in the site level acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp allows the supplier to participate in the testing, the supplier should never be in control of the acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp permits supplier participation in testing, the supplier must never control the acceptance tests.
content.expert_insight: Maintaining control over acceptance testing is paramount for Zebracorp to ensure impartiality and protect its interests, preventing potential conflicts of interest.
content.conditions: Zebracorp allows supplier participation in testing.
content.justification: To maintain impartiality and protect Zebracorp's interests.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure it retains full control over the acceptance testing process, even with supplier involvement.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may participate but must not attempt to control the acceptance tests.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp allows the supplier to participate in the testing, the supplier should never be in control of the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Once the results of services/deliverables pass the acceptance tests and otherwise fulfil the required acceptance criteria, Zebracorp would typically be required to issue a written acceptance certificate evidencing the completion of acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: Upon successful completion of acceptance tests and fulfillment of criteria, Zebracorp is usually required to issue a written acceptance certificate.
content.expert_insight: A formal written certificate provides clear documentation of acceptance, which is vital for triggering payments, starting warranties, and closing out project phases.
content.conditions: Results of services/deliverables pass acceptance tests and fulfill required acceptance criteria.
content.justification: To formally document and evidence the completion of acceptance tests.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has an obligation to issue a written acceptance certificate once conditions are met.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect a written acceptance certificate upon successful completion of tests, which is crucial for their revenue recognition and payment.
content.text: Once the results of services/deliverables pass the acceptance tests and otherwise fulfil the required acceptance criteria, Zebracorp would typically be required to issue a written acceptance certificate evidencing the completion of acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Provisional acceptance is often granted at the point in time when the deliverables substantially meet the agreed acceptance criteria.
content.plain_text: Provisional acceptance is typically granted when deliverables largely satisfy the agreed acceptance criteria.
content.expert_insight: This allows for partial project completion and potentially partial payment while minor issues are still being resolved, facilitating project flow.
content.justification: Defines provisional acceptance.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Provisional acceptance is often granted at the point in time when the deliverables substantially meet the agreed acceptance criteria.

content.verbatim_text: Final acceptance will be granted subsequently once all errors and deficiencies identified during the provisional acceptance tests have been remedied and the end customer has accepted the product.
content.plain_text: Final acceptance is granted after all provisional acceptance issues are resolved and the end customer has accepted the product.
content.expert_insight: Final acceptance signifies complete project closure from a quality and contractual standpoint, often linked to end-customer satisfaction.
content.justification: Defines final acceptance.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Final acceptance will be granted subsequently once all errors and deficiencies identified during the provisional acceptance tests have been remedied and the end customer has accepted the product.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp can agree to system element based or other partial acceptance only so long as this is in line with the corresponding acceptance provisions of our customer contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can only agree to partial or system-element-based acceptance if it aligns with the customer contract's acceptance provisions.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates the crucial 'back-to-back' alignment principle, preventing Zebracorp from prematurely accepting parts of a system from a supplier if the end customer's contract doesn't allow for such partial acceptance.
content.conditions: Agreement to system element based or other partial acceptance.
content.justification: To ensure alignment with customer contract provisions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must verify alignment with customer contracts before agreeing to partial acceptance from suppliers, to avoid contractual discrepancies.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers seeking partial acceptance should be aware that Zebracorp's ability to grant it depends on its own customer contracts.
content.text: Zebracorp can agree to system element based or other partial acceptance only so long as this is in line with the corresponding acceptance provisions of our customer contract.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that in the majority of cases we may be able to agree to acceptance being deemed to take place without us issuing a formal acceptance certificate when the a certain time period for completing the acceptance tests has passed (“backstop date”), or when we or our customers takes the results of the works into commercial or production use (“deemed acceptance”).
content.plain_text: Acceptance can be 'deemed' to occur without a formal certificate if a 'backstop date' (a time limit for tests) passes, or if Zebracorp or its customers start commercial or production use of the deliverables.
content.expert_insight: These are important concepts for streamlining the acceptance process but carry risks if not carefully managed. 'Deemed acceptance' can prevent project stagnation but requires careful monitoring.
content.justification: Defines 'backstop date' and 'deemed acceptance'.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.text: Note also that in the majority of cases we may be able to agree to acceptance being deemed to take place without us issuing a formal acceptance certificate when the a certain time period for completing the acceptance tests has passed (“backstop date”), or when we or our customers takes the results of the works into commercial or production use (“deemed acceptance”).

content.verbatim_text: It is however recommended to verify that such deemed acceptance or backstop dates are also agreed in our corresponding customer contract (if applicable) to make sure the acceptance provisions are back-to-back.
content.plain_text: It is recommended to ensure that deemed acceptance or backstop dates are also included in corresponding customer contracts for back-to-back alignment.
content.expert_insight: This is crucial to prevent Zebracorp from being deemed to have accepted a supplier's work while still awaiting formal acceptance from its own customer, creating a potential liability gap.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To ensure acceptance provisions are back-to-back with customer contracts.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should proactively align these dates with customer contracts to avoid being bound by deemed acceptance before its customer.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will seek to align these terms with its customer contracts, potentially impacting their deemed acceptance timelines.
content.text: It is however recommended to verify that such deemed acceptance or backstop dates are also agreed in our corresponding customer contract (if applicable) to make sure the acceptance provisions are back-to-back.

content.verbatim_text: It is also worth checking with the respective project manager that Zebracorp has sufficient time to complete system level testing before any deemed acceptance is being triggered.
content.plain_text: Project managers should confirm Zebracorp has enough time for system-level testing before deemed acceptance is triggered.
content.expert_insight: This internal check is vital to prevent acceptance of untested or inadequately tested systems, which could lead to significant downstream issues and costs.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To ensure sufficient time for testing before deemed acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must manage its internal testing schedules to avoid premature deemed acceptance of deliverables.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from Zebracorp's internal checks, as it ensures a thorough testing process before acceptance.
content.text: It is also worth checking with the respective project manager that Zebracorp has sufficient time to complete system level testing before any deemed acceptance is being triggered.

content.verbatim_text: When agreeing on a backstop date for completing the acceptance test, we should ensure that acceptance is not triggered, if the delay in completing the acceptance tests is not caused by reasons solely attributable to ZEBRACORP.
content.plain_text: When setting a backstop date for acceptance tests, ensure acceptance isn't triggered if Zebracorp is not solely responsible for testing delays.
content.expert_insight: This protects Zebracorp from being forced into deemed acceptance due to supplier delays or external factors, maintaining its right to proper testing.
content.conditions: Agreeing on a backstop date for completing acceptance tests.
content.justification: To prevent acceptance being triggered due to delays not attributable to Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must negotiate backstop dates carefully to include clauses protecting against deemed acceptance if delays are not its fault.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will seek to avoid deemed acceptance if supplier-caused delays impact testing.
content.text: When agreeing on a backstop date for completing the acceptance test, we should ensure that acceptance is not triggered, if the delay in completing the acceptance tests is not caused by reasons solely attributable to ZEBRACORP.

content.verbatim_text: Any deficiencies, errors or deviations found in the subcontractor’s performance should automatically result in an extension of time for completing the acceptance tests.
content.plain_text: Subcontractor performance deficiencies, errors, or deviations should automatically extend the acceptance test period.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical clause for Zebracorp, ensuring that the discovery of issues during testing does not force premature acceptance but instead grants necessary time for remediation and re-testing.
content.conditions: Deficiencies, errors, or deviations found in subcontractor's performance.
content.justification: To allow for remediation and re-testing without triggering premature acceptance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp benefits from extended testing time to ensure issues are resolved before acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect that deficiencies will extend the acceptance period, requiring them to remedy issues before final acceptance.
content.text: Any deficiencies, errors or deviations found in the subcontractor’s performance should automatically result in an extension of time for completing the acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Also it is always recommended to have the subcontractor agree to send a final formal written notice to us and agree to give us a reasonable cure period before granting deemed acceptance.
content.plain_text: It is recommended that subcontractors agree to send a final written notice and allow a reasonable cure period before deemed acceptance is granted.
content.expert_insight: This provides an additional safeguard against inadvertent deemed acceptance, giving Zebracorp a final opportunity to complete tests or address issues.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: To avoid granting acceptance inadvertently for something not properly tested.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should negotiate this clause to gain a final warning and cure period before deemed acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to agree to provide such a written reminder and cure period.
content.text: Also it is always recommended to have the subcontractor agree to send a final formal written notice to us and agree to give us a reasonable cure period before granting deemed acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever Zebracorp has agreed to such evaluation period, it is important to have our respective subcontractors for that particular customer agree to similar commercial evaluation period before granting Final Acceptance.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp agrees to a customer evaluation period, subcontractors for that project must agree to a similar commercial evaluation period before final acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This is another 'back-to-back' alignment requirement, ensuring Zebracorp doesn't accept and pay for a subcontractor's work while its own customer is still evaluating it.
content.conditions: Zebracorp has agreed to a customer evaluation period (e.g., Product or System Performance Evaluation Period).
content.justification: To align acceptance provisions with customer contracts and avoid Zebracorp accepting deliverables prematurely.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its subcontractor contracts mirror customer evaluation periods to avoid financial exposure.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must agree to commercial evaluation periods if Zebracorp has done so with its end customer, potentially delaying their final acceptance.
content.text: Whenever Zebracorp has agreed to such evaluation period, it is important to have our respective subcontractors for that particular customer agree to similar commercial evaluation period before granting Final Acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: Having clear acceptance criteria in the contract will benefit both parties.
content.plain_text: Clear acceptance criteria in contracts benefit both the buyer and the seller.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental principle of good contract management, reducing ambiguity and potential for disputes.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Clear criteria help Zebracorp ensure it receives what it expects and reduces disputes.
content.implication_supplier: Clear criteria provide suppliers with a definitive target for their deliverables, reducing uncertainty.
content.text: Having clear acceptance criteria in the contract will benefit both parties.

content.verbatim_text: Such subjective or unilateral criteria can, with the assistance of Zebracorp product line or customer team, be replaced by objective and clearly defined acceptance criteria. In fact, this approach would be preferred over agreeing to language where we merely state that acceptance test will be passed when the deliverables ‘substantially conform’ or “materially comply” with the agreed specifications.
content.plain_text: Subjective acceptance criteria (e.g., 'to reasonable satisfaction') should be replaced with objective, clearly defined criteria, preferably over ambiguous terms like 'substantially conform' or 'materially comply'.
content.expert_insight: Objective criteria are essential for measurable outcomes and dispute avoidance. Ambiguous language is a common pitfall that can lead to protracted disagreements.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Subjective or ambiguous language is prone to disputes.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should actively seek objective criteria to ensure clear expectations and reduce dispute risk.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from objective criteria, as it provides a clear target for their deliverables, reducing uncertainty and dispute potential.
content.text: Such subjective or unilateral criteria can, with the assistance of Zebracorp product line or customer team, be replaced by objective and clearly defined acceptance criteria. In fact, this approach would be preferred over agreeing to language where we merely state that acceptance test will be passed when the deliverables ‘substantially conform’ or “materially comply” with the agreed specifications.

content.verbatim_text: In some instances we can agree that minor deficiencies/errors found during the acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works will not prevent acceptance, but will be remedied by the subcontractor as part of its warranty obligations or within a certain mutually agreed timeframe.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can agree that minor, non-critical deficiencies found during testing won't prevent acceptance, provided the subcontractor remedies them under warranty or a separate agreed timeframe.
content.expert_insight: This offers flexibility, allowing projects to move forward despite minor issues, but requires clear agreement on remediation and warranty terms.
content.conditions: Minor deficiencies/errors found during acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works.
content.justification: To allow for acceptance while ensuring minor issues are still addressed.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept deliverables with minor issues, but must ensure robust warranty or remediation clauses are in place.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may achieve acceptance despite minor issues, but remain obligated to remedy them under warranty or a separate agreement.
content.text: In some instances we can agree that minor deficiencies/errors found during the acceptance tests that do not prevent the intended use of the results of the works will not prevent acceptance, but will be remedied by the subcontractor as part of its warranty obligations or within a certain mutually agreed timeframe.

content.verbatim_text: Again, in those subcontracts where the supplier is delivering the deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer, it is naturally important that the acceptance is sufficiently aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.
content.plain_text: For subcontracts where suppliers deliver directly to Zebracorp’s customers, acceptance must be well-aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This is a reiteration of the critical 'back-to-back' principle, emphasizing its importance in direct-to-customer scenarios to avoid Zebracorp being caught in the middle.
content.conditions: Supplier is delivering deliverables directly to Zebracorp's customer.
content.justification: To ensure alignment and prevent Zebracorp from accepting deliverables before its own customer.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its subcontractor acceptance terms mirror its customer acceptance terms to avoid liability and contractual discrepancies.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers delivering directly to Zebracorp's customers will have their acceptance tied to the end-customer's acceptance process.
content.text: Again, in those subcontracts where the supplier is delivering the deliverables directly to Zebracorp’s customer, it is naturally important that the acceptance is sufficiently aligned with Zebracorp’s customer acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: The completion of acceptance should be subject to the successful completion of acceptance tests that are performed by either Zebracorp or our end customers, or, as applicable, both jointly.
content.plain_text: Acceptance completion should depend on successful acceptance tests performed by Zebracorp, end customers, or both jointly.
content.expert_insight: This defines Zebracorp's preferred position on who performs the critical acceptance tests, ensuring control and alignment with its customer-facing obligations.

content.justification: Zebracorp's preferred position to ensure proper verification.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp prefers to control or co-control acceptance testing to ensure quality and alignment with customer needs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect acceptance to be contingent on tests performed by Zebracorp and/or its end customers.
content.text: The completion of acceptance should be subject to the successful completion of acceptance tests that are performed by either Zebracorp or our end customers, or, as applicable, both jointly.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier/subcontractor participation to the acceptance tests will be at the discretion of Zebracorp and our end customer, as applicable.
content.plain_text: Supplier/subcontractor participation in acceptance tests is at the discretion of Zebracorp and/or its end customer.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces Zebracorp's control over the testing process, allowing it to decide when and how suppliers are involved.
content.conditions: N/A
content.justification: Zebracorp's preferred position to maintain control over the testing process.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains the right to decide if and how suppliers participate in acceptance tests.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' involvement in acceptance tests is not guaranteed and depends on Zebracorp's discretion.
content.text: The supplier/subcontractor participation to the acceptance tests will be at the discretion of Zebracorp and our end customer, as applicable.

content.plain_text: Contracts should grant Zebracorp adequate time to finish acceptance tests.

content.verbatim_text: Failure to complete the tests in a timely manner should not automatically lead to deemed acceptance, but the supplier/subcontractor should first be required to notify Zebracorp in writing and request Zebracorp to complete the acceptance within a reasonable time frame.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's failure to timely complete tests should not automatically trigger deemed acceptance; instead, the supplier must first provide written notice and request Zebracorp to complete acceptance within a reasonable timeframe.
content.expert_insight: This is a key protective clause for Zebracorp, preventing inadvertent acceptance due to internal delays and ensuring a formal process for triggering deemed acceptance.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must formally notify Zebracorp and provide a cure period before deemed acceptance can be triggered due to Zebracorp's delay.
content.text: Failure to complete the tests in a timely manner should not automatically lead to deemed acceptance, but the supplier/subcontractor should first be required to notify Zebracorp in writing and request Zebracorp to complete the acceptance within a reasonable time frame.

content.verbatim_text: Acceptance should be either final, partial or conditional as indicated by Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should have the discretion to indicate whether acceptance is final, partial, or conditional.
content.expert_insight: This ensures Zebracorp retains control over the type of acceptance granted, aligning it with project status and risk management.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' acceptance may be partial or conditional at Zebracorp's discretion.
content.text: Acceptance should be either final, partial or conditional as indicated by Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: “The [Supplier] shall notify Zebracorp in writing when the [Supplier] considers that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been completed in accordance with this [Agreement], and request [Zebracorp] to initiate the acceptance tests. Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question. Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate. In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance. The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action. [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”
content.plain_text: This is an example of an acceptance procedure provision reflecting Zebracorp's preferred position, detailing supplier notification, Zebracorp's 30-day review and certificate issuance, Zebracorp's right to refuse acceptance with reasons, supplier's obligation to remedy deficiencies, and Zebracorp's condition for issuing acceptance certificates.
content.expert_insight: This example clause provides a robust framework for acceptance, clearly delineating responsibilities and timelines for both parties, and safeguarding Zebracorp's interests by ensuring remediation before final acceptance.
content.justification: Provided as an example of Zebracorp's preferred acceptance procedure provision.
content.implication_company: This example reflects Zebracorp's desired contractual terms for acceptance, giving it control over the process, timelines, and conditions for acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers would be obligated to follow this detailed procedure, including notification, remediation of defects, and awaiting Zebracorp's satisfaction before final acceptance.

Within thirty (30) days of receipt of such written notice [Zebracorp] shall, if satisfied that the [Works] or the relevant milestone has been duly completed and the agreed acceptance criteria is met, issue a certificate of acceptance for the milestone in question. Such acceptance can be partial or conditional as indicated in [Zebracorp’] acceptance certificate. In the event that [Zebracorp] is not satisfied that the [Works] and/or the relevant milestone has been completed or if the agreed acceptance criteria or other agreed requirements are not met, [Zebracorp] shall notify [Supplier] thereof within the aforementioned time limit and, at the request of the [Supplier], provide the reasons for refusing the acceptance. The [Supplier] shall promptly remedy any failures or deficiencies in meeting the acceptance criteria set out below and/or such other agreed requirements, and also rectify and remedy any and all defects and deficiencies identified by [Zebracorp] and/or [Zebracorp’s] customer during the acceptance tests and inform [Zebracorp] in writing upon completing such remedial action. [Zebracorp] will issue the certificate of acceptance only after having satisfied itself that such deficiencies and defects have been duly remedied and rectified, and the [Works] or the relevant part thereof has been completed and all of the requirements for issuing the certificate of acceptance in this [Agreement] have been met.”

content.verbatim_text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.plain_text: For subcontracts tied to specific end customer projects, acceptance criteria and procedures must always align with the end customer's acceptance provisions.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental and repeated principle, emphasizing the critical importance of 'back-to-back' alignment to prevent Zebracorp from being in a position where it has accepted supplier work but its customer has not.
content.conditions: Subcontracts specifically made for a particular end customer project.
content.justification: To ensure consistency and avoid discrepancies between Zebracorp's obligations to its customer and its rights/obligations with its subcontractor.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must meticulously align these provisions to avoid contractual gaps and potential liability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' acceptance will be directly linked to the end customer's acceptance process and criteria.
content.text: The acceptance criteria and acceptance procedures should always be aligned with the end customer acceptance provisions in any such subcontracts that are specifically made for a particular end customer project.
